1. Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies:

At our power plants, we handle isobutane, isopentane and pentane which are considered hazardous flammables by the US EPA. The same properties that make these regulated substances valuable as a working fluid for the power plants also make it necessary to observe certain safety precautions in handling these substances to prevent unnecessary human exposure,  to reduce the threat to our own personal health as well as our facility staff personnel, and to reduce the threat to our community. It is our policy to adhere to all applicable federal, state and local rules and regulations. Safety depends upon the manner in which we handle these regulated substances combined with the safety devices inherent in the design of these facilities combined with the safe handling procedures that we use and the training of our personnel. 

Since our operators do not respond to large chemical releases, we have implemented an Emergency Action Plan which includes procedures for handling small releases of hazardous chemicals as required by OSHA under 29 CFR 1910.38.

2.  Facility and regulated substances handled:

The purpose of our operation is to generate electricity by utilizing the geothermal resource as a source of energy. Our facilities are located nine miles south of Reno, Nevada and includes eight power plants designated as SB1, SB1A, SB2, SB3, Galena 1, Galena 2, Galena 3, and Steamboat Hills. The SB1 and SB1A power plants are co-located at the northwest corner of the site and use the regulated substances pentane and isopentane, respectively, as the working fluids. The SB2 and SB3 power plants are located in the northwest corner of the site and both use the regulated substance isobutane as the working fluid. Galena 1 is located about 100 yards north of the SB1/SB1A system.  Galena 3 is located a half mile northwest of the SB2 and SB3 Facility. Galena 1 and Galena 3 are virtually identical to each other, the both utiliz

e Pentane as their motive fluid.  Galena 2 and Steamboat hills are located 1.5 miles north of Galena 1, They both utilize pentane as their motive fluid.  

- Geothermal Energy and Power Plants
Geothermal energy is renewable heat energy from the earths core. Geothermal reservoirs of hot water or steam are tapped with wells and their heat is converted to electricity. At the Steamboat Power Plants, Galena 1, and Galena 3,  geothermal brine at a temperature of 300?-315? F is pumped from production wells drilled into the geothermal reservoir. The brine is kept under pressure to keep it from flashing to steam as it is piped through the plant to the heat exchangers where the heat is extracted from the brine and is used to heat a working fluid (isobutane, isopentane, or pentane) to a vapor. The used brine is injected back into the geothermal reservoir keeping the cycle closed. The vapor is piped through the blades of a turbine, spinning the turbine which is connected to a generator and produces electricity. The hot vapor is piped through air-cooled condensers, transforming it back to a fluid. The fluid is cycled back to the heat exchangers in a closed-loop system and the process starts again.
Galena 2 runs much the same as the lower steamboat plants, but rather than keeping the brine under intense pressure to keep it a liquid, the geothermal fluid coming out of the ground is separated into steam and brine lines.  Galena has a preheater that is heated by hot brine, and a vaporizer that is heated by steam.  After the steam runs through the vaporizer, it condenses into water and then runs through a recuperator where it preheats the water going into the preheater.  The condensed is steam then mixed into the brine, and then pumped back into the ground at one of our injection wells.

Our Steamboat hills facility or SBH has two turbines, one known as the STG, and the other known as OEC 41 or SBHE.  The STG is a steam flash turbine, and OEC 41 is a binary cycle that utilizes Pentan

e as it?s motive fluid. Rather than using steam in the vaporizer and brine in the preheater, the Steamboat hills plant sends all the brine through OEC 41, and the steam through the STG.  The condensed steam is ran through a water cooled condenser where it is condensed.   The water that comes out of the STG is then ran through a cooling tower and used to condense the pentane coming out of OEC 41.  Any water that isn?t lost to the atmosphere is then mixed with the outgoing brine on OEC 41 and sent back to injection

-  SB1 & SB1A Overview
The SB1 and SB1A Power Plants were developed by Ormat, Inc in 1984 and 1987, respectively. Collectively, SB1 and SB1A produce approximately 7 megawatts (gross) of electricity daily and sell the power to Sierra Pacific Power Company.

SB1 uses approximately 85,000 pounds of pentane and SB1A uses approximately 25,000 pounds of isopentane within their closed-loop systems.

-  SB2 & SB3 Overview
The SB2 and SB3 Power Plants were developed by Steamboat Development Corporation in 1992. In February 2004 Ormat Nevada, Inc assumed the operation of these two plants, while retaining the entire operations, maintenance and management staff. Collectively, SB2 and SB3 produce approximately 40 megawatts (gross) of electricity daily and sell the power to Sierra Pacific Power Company under a 30 year power purchase agreement.

Together, the plants use about 660,000pounds of isobutane as the working fluid within their closed-loop systems.

-Galena 1 Overview
The Galena 1 facility was developed in 2005 by Ormat Inc. The facility produces approximately 20 MW of electricity and sells the electricity to Sierra Pacific Power Company

Galena uses 78,000 pounds of pentane as the working fluid in a closed loop

-Galena 2 Overview
The Galena 2 facility was developed in 2006 by Ormat Inc. The facility produces approximately 10 MW of electricity and sells the electricity to Sierra Pacific Power Company

Galena uses 136,700 pounds of pentane as the working fluid in

a closed loop system.

-Galena 3 Overview
The Galena 3 facility is currently being developed by Ormat Inc. The facility will be online in late 2007 and will produce approximately 20 MW of electricity and sell the electricity to Sierra Pacific Power Company

Galena 3 will uses 78,000 pounds of pentane as the working fluid in a closed loop

-Steamboat Hills Overview
The Steamboat Hills facility was developed in 1987 by Caithness Power L.L.C. originally the plan consisted of a single steam powered turbine.  The facility was purchaced by Ormat in 2004 and in 2006 an Ormat bottoming unit was installed that uses the brine that is unable to run through the turbine.  Together the STG and OEC 41 can put out approximately15 MW of power that is sold to Sierra Pacific Power Company.

 Steamboat Hills uses 50,706 pounds of pentane as the working fluid in a closed loop


3.  General accidental release prevention program and specific prevention steps:

The Accidental Release Prevention Program focuses primarily upon the proper training and actions of our operators as outlined by OSHA's  Process Safety Management (PSM), EPA's Risk Management Plan (RMP), and NDEP's Chemical Accident Prevention Program (CAPP). The Training Program, Standard Operating Procedures, Incident Investigation Program, and Management of Change Program ensure that the operator is aware of all potential hazards as well as the measures to mitigate them. 

The Preventive Maintenance and Mechanical Integrity Program is essential in maintaining the integrity of the equipment. Monthly emission  inspections for leaks, at all valve packing and piping flanges, and the proper operation of equipment also play a critical role in our prevention program.

In addition the Accidental Release Prevention Program relies upon safeguards inherent to the design of the power plant. Such safeguards include gas sensors and alarms, relief valves, manual and automatic shut-offs, interlocks, vents, and check valves. 

In the event of a

fire, the plants are equipped with a sprinkler system, deluge system, fire monitors and hydrants.

4.  Five Year Incident History:

We have had no accidental isobutane, isopentane or pentane releases in the last five years that resulted in deaths, injuries, property damage, or known offsite deaths, injuries, property damage, or environmental damage, evacuations, or sheltering-in-place.

5.  Planned changes to improve safety:

Our plants have been operating safely for many years, we will continue to ensure extensive training is provided to are operators as they are essential to plant safety. 

In addition we will evaluate any new mitigation or control technology that may improve safety at the Steamboat Facilities.
